definitions.definition: to have information in your mind as a result of experience or because you have learned or been told it
definitions.sensetop: know somethingknow (that)…it is known that…know where, who, etc…know about somethingknow of somebody/somethingknow to do somethingknow somebody/something to be/do something

examples.text: No one **knows the answer**.
I need to **know your name**.
The truth about what happened is not yet known.
**All I know** is that she used to work in a bank *(= I have no other information about her)*.
I know (that) people’s handwriting changes as they get older.
We **know from experience** that turning a hobby into a business is not easy.
I **know for a fact **(that) he didn't go to the party.
‘There's no one in.’ ‘**How do you know?**’
‘You've got a flat tyre.’ ‘I know.’
‘What's the answer?’ ‘I don't know.’
**As you know**, Emma and I are old friends.
‘Isn’t that his car?’ ‘**I wouldn’t know./How should I know?**’ *(= I don’t know and I am not the person you should ask.)*
‘What are you two whispering about?’ ‘**You don't want to know**’ *(= because you would be shocked or wouldn't approve)*.
It is widely known that CFCs can damage the ozone layer.
I knew where he was hiding.
No one **knows for sure** who did it.
You know about Amanda's baby, don't you?
**I don't know about you, but** I'm ready for something to eat.
I **know next to nothing** *(= know almost nothing)* about opera.
I know of someone who can help us.
‘Is anyone else coming?’ ‘**Not that I know of.**’
Does he know to come here *(= that he should come here)* first?
We know her to be honest.
Strobe lights are known to cause seizures.
Do you know his address?
The cause of the fire is not yet known.
Two women are known to have died.
I didn't know what he was talking about.
I need to know what everyone thinks about this.
‘He's feeling really down.’ ‘ I know.’
She knows a lot about early music.
I don't know much about art.
I don't know for certain, but I think she lives in the next town.
I don't know of anyone who might be interested in the job.
I honestly don't know what they mean to do.
The properties of this substance are poorly known.
If you don't know how to fill in the forms, just ask.

phrases: know a lot, nothing, very little, etc.

definitions.definition: to realize, understand or be aware of something

examples.text: As soon as I walked in the room I knew (that) something was wrong.
She knew she was dying.
‘Martin was lying all the time.’ ‘**I should have known**.’
I knew perfectly well what she meant.
I **know exactly** how you feel.
This case is hopeless **and he knows it** *(= although he will not admit it)*.
If only we'd known you were having so many problems!
You know very well what I'm talking about!
If I'd known beforehand how bad it would be, I wouldn't have gone.
I instantly knew what the call was about.
He knew instinctively where he would find her.

phrases: the next thing I, he, etc. knew

definitions.definition: to feel certain about something

examples.text: He knew (that) he could trust her.
I know it's here somewhere!
I know things will turn out all right.
I don't know that I can finish it by next week.
I just knew that it was something I wanted to do.
‘You were right—someone's been spreading rumours about you.’ ‘I knew it!’
‘She's the worst player in the team.’ ‘Oh, **I don't know** *(= I am not sure that I agree)*—she played well yesterday.’
She knew deep down that she would never see him again.
He knew that he could trust her.
I just knew there would be problems.

phrases: the next thing I, he, etc. knew

definitions.definition: to be familiar with a person, place, thing, etc.

examples.text: I've known David for 20 years.
Do you two know each other *(= have you met before)*?
She was a secretary when I first knew her.
She's very nice when you **get to know** her.
**Knowing Ben**, we could be waiting a long time *(= it is typical of him to be late)*.
This man **is known to the police** *(= as a criminal)*.
I don’t know anyone in Oxford.
I **know** Paris **well**.
Do you know the play *(= have you seen or read it before)*?
How many of your neighbours do you **know by name**?
The new rules could mean the end of football **as we know it** *(= in the form that we are familiar with)*.
He knows this city better than anyone.
I don't know them personally.
I don't know John very well.
But I hardly know the woman!
I know several people who could help.
The product our consumers know and love will not change.

definitions.definition: to have learned a skill or language and be able to use it
definitions.sensetop: know somethingknow how to do something

examples.text: Do you know any Japanese?
Do you know how to use spreadsheets?

definitions.definition: to think that somebody/something is a particular type of person or thing or has particular characteristics
definitions.sensetop: be known as somethingbe known for somethingbe known to be/do something

examples.text: He has become **widely known** as an expert in child psychology.
It's known as the most dangerous part of the city.
She is **best known** for her work on the human brain.
He is internationally known for his work with vaccines.
He's known to be an outstanding physicist.

definitions.definition: to give somebody/something a particular name or title
definitions.sensetop: be known as somebody/somethingbe known as somebody/something to somebodybe known by something

examples.text: Iran was **formerly known** as Persia.
The H5N1 virus is **more commonly known** as bird flu.
Peter Wilson, **also known** as ‘The Tiger’
He was known as Bonzo to his friends.
examples.contextForm: be known as somebody/something to somebody

examples.text: The country was not yet **known by the name of** England.
parts of the body known collectively as the sensory system
St Petersburg is variously known as the ‘Venice of the North’, ‘second Amsterdam’ or ‘northern Rome’.
He has been known by many names in his long life.

definitions.definition: to be able to recognize somebody/something

examples.text: I couldn't see who was speaking, but I knew the voice.
She knows a bargain when she sees one.

definitions.definition: to understand the difference between one person or thing and another

examples.text: I hope we have taught our children to know right from wrong.

definitions.definition: to have seen, heard or experienced something
definitions.sensetop: know somebody/something (to) do somethingbe known to do something

examples.text: I’ve never known it (to) snow in July before.
He has been known to spend all morning in the bathroom.

definitions.definition: to have personal experience of something

examples.text: He has known both poverty and wealth.
She may be successful now, but she has **known what it is like to be** poor.
She thought she would never know the joy of seeing a child grow up in her care.

definitions.definition: used to say that you think you know, remember, understand, etc. something but you cannot be completely sure, especially because you do not know all the facts

examples.text: As far as we knew, there was no cause for concern.
As far as I can see, you've done nothing wrong.
She lived in Chicago, as far as I can remember.

definitions.definition: very quickly or suddenly

examples.text: We were whisked off in a taxi before we knew where we were.

definitions.definition: to have no way of realizing or being aware that you have done something wrong

examples.text: ‘I'm sorry, I called when you were in bed.’ ‘Don't worry—you weren't to know.’

definitions.definition: used to say that it is easier and wiser to stay in a bad situation that you know and can deal with rather than change to a new situation that may be much worse
used to emphasize that you do not know something and that it is not important to you

examples.text: She could be dead for all I know.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize that you do not know something

examples.text: God knows what else they might find.
‘Where are they?’ ‘Goodness knows.’

definitions.definition: used to emphasize the truth of what you are saying

examples.text: She ought to pass the exam—goodness knows she's been working hard enough.

definitions.definition: to be confident that you know something, especially when you actually do not

examples.text: He thinks he knows all the answers.

definitions.definition: to know something perfectly so that you can repeat it at any time without having to think about it

examples.text: He had all the answers off pat.

definitions.definition: to be in poor condition

examples.text: Our car has seen better days!

definitions.definition: used to criticize somebody’s behaviour

examples.text: I don't know how you can say things like that.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody the true facts about a situation, especially when these are not known by other people

examples.text: If the truth be known, I was afraid to tell anyone.

definitions.definition: used to agree with somebody or to show sympathy

examples.text: ‘What a ridiculous situation!’ ‘I know.’

definitions.definition: used to introduce a new idea or suggestion

examples.text: I know, let's see what's on at the theatre.

definitions.definition: used to criticize somebody by saying that they should realize or understand something

examples.text: You know as well as I do that you're being unreasonable.

definitions.definition: to know somebody/something extremely well

examples.text: She must know the play backwards by now.

definitions.definition: to know what should be done, etc. better than other people

examples.text: The doctor told you to stay in bed, and she knows best.

definitions.definition: to be sensible enough not to do something

examples.text: He knows better than to judge by appearances.

definitions.definition: to recognize somebody without knowing them well
to have information or evidence that the opposite is true

examples.text: He says he doesn't care about what the critics write, but I know different.

definitions.definition: to be very aware of a fact and unable to deny or ignore it

examples.text: He knew full well what she thought of it.

definitions.definition: to be very familiar with somebody/something

examples.text: This is where I grew up. I know this area like the back of my hand.

definitions.definition: to have very clear and definite ideas about what you want to do
to know a lot about a particular subject or job
to know/tell somebody some useful, interesting or surprising information about somebody/something

examples.text: She's been married five times, so she knows a thing or two about men!

definitions.definition: to know something because of something unpleasant that has happened to you

examples.text: She is a tough competitor, as I know to my cost.

definitions.definition: to be familiar with a place, subject, etc.
to have knowledge about something from your own experience

examples.text: I worked there for 20 years, so I know what I'm talking about.

definitions.definition: to know where you can get an advantage for yourself
to make sure that people are informed about something, especially by getting somebody else to tell them

examples.text: The President has let it be known that he does not intend to run for election again.

definitions.definition: to tell somebody about something

examples.text: I don't know if I can come, but I'll let you know tomorrow.
Let me know how I can help.
Please let me know if there's anything I can do to help.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize what you are saying

examples.text: Lord knows, I tried to teach her.

definitions.definition: used to say that you do not know the answer to something

examples.text: ‘Why did she say that?’ ‘Lord knows!’

definitions.definition: to introduce yourself to somebody

examples.text: I made myself known to the hotel manager.

definitions.definition: to behave badly, usually because you have not been taught the correct way to behave

examples.text: Don’t blame the children—they don’t know any better.

definitions.definition: to be very stupid; to have absolutely no skill
to know nothing about a subject

examples.text: I don’t know beans about making movies.

definitions.definition: to know nothing at all about somebody/something

examples.text: I’m afraid I don’t know the first thing about cars.

definitions.definition: to know nothing at all about something/somebody

examples.text: We’ve lived next to him for years, but we still don’t know the first thing about him.

definitions.definition: to not know at all who somebody is
to be so surprised by something that you do not know how to react
to feel very embarrassed and not know how to react
to be so excited or confused that you cannot behave or think in a sensible way
to have an easy life without realizing how easy it is

examples.text: You people without kids don't know you're born.

definitions.definition: to take no interest in something because you do not care about it or it is too much trouble

examples.text: I've tried to ask her advice, but she doesn't want to know *(= about my problems)*.
‘How much was it?’ ‘**You don't want to know**’ *(= it is better if you don't know)*.

definitions.definition: old enough to behave in a more sensible way than you actually did
to show somebody/know/learn how a particular job should be done
used to say that it is impossible to say what might happen

examples.text: There's no knowing how he'll react.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody knows nothing about the subject you are talking about

examples.text: What does he know about football, anyway?

definitions.definition: used to express surprise

examples.text: Well, what do you know? Look who's here!

definitions.definition: (know) what things are useful, important, etc.

examples.text: She certainly knows what's what.

definitions.definition: used when you are thinking of what to say next

examples.text: Well, you know, it's difficult to explain.

definitions.definition: used to show that what you are referring to is known or understood by the person you are speaking to

examples.text: Guess who I've just seen? Maggie! You know—Jim's wife.
You know that restaurant round the corner? It's closed down.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize something that you are saying

examples.text: I'm not stupid, you know.

definitions.definition: used to introduce an interesting or surprising opinion, piece of news, etc.

examples.text: You know something? I've never really enjoyed Christmas.

definitions.definition: used to refer to somebody/something without mentioning a name
used to say that you can never be certain about what will happen in the future, especially when you are suggesting that something good might happen

wordOrigin: Old English cnāwan (earlier gecnāwan) ‘recognize, identify’, of Germanic origin; from an Indo-European root shared by Latin (g)noscere, Greek gignōskein, also by can and ken.
